channel.title: tastytrade: Options Jive
channel.description: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Learn to talk the talk - sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss trading topics of the day.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade
channel.itunes:summary: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: Product Size Comparison
item.description: Trading options on equity indexes has many avenues that are all liquid. The only tangible difference to traders between the products is the notional size of the product and the buying power reduction of the position.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Trading options on equity indexes has many avenues that are all liquid. The only tangible difference to traders between the products is the notional size of the product and the buying power reduction of the position.
item.content:encoded: Trading options on equity indexes has many avenues that are all liquid. The only tangible difference to traders between the products is the notional size of the product and the buying power reduction of the position.

item.title: Standard Deviation of PL
item.description: While the first goal of a trader is to make money, the second goal is to do so consistently. Looking at the standard deviation of profit and loss gives us a useful metric on the unreliability of trading strategies. Tom and Tony take a look.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: While the first goal of a trader is to make money, the second goal is to do so consistently. Looking at the standard deviation of profit and loss gives us a useful metric on the unreliability of trading strategies. Tom and Tony take a look.
item.content:encoded: While the first goal of a trader is to make money, the second goal is to do so consistently. Looking at the standard deviation of profit and loss gives us a useful metric on the unreliability of trading strategies. Tom and Tony take a look.

item.title: POT vs Prob of ITM
item.description: The probability of touch is the probability that a strike will be tested by the underlying before expiration. The statistic is approximated by multiplying the option’s delta (or Prob ITM) by two. Knowing defensive adjustment tactics for when a strike gets breached is important. Since the POT of strangles is usually well above 50%, you will experience more tested positions than not.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: The probability of touch is the probability that a strike will be tested by the underlying before expiration. The statistic is approximated by multiplying the option’s delta (or Prob ITM) by two. Knowing defensive adjustment tactics for when a str...
item.content:encoded: The probability of touch is the probability that a strike will be tested by the underlying before expiration. The statistic is approximated by multiplying the option’s delta (or Prob ITM) by two. Knowing defensive adjustment tactics for when a strike gets breached is important. Since the POT of strangles is usually well above 50%, you will experience more tested positions than not.

item.title: Rule of Thumb to Diversification
item.description: In low IV environments, diversifying portfolios is easy because non-correlated underlyings are plentiful. The risk of a portfolio that only contains non-correlated stock is understated because stock correlations increase in periods of high IV. By utilizing other asset classes and option strategies in our portfolios, we may diversify away more risk because those assets and strategies tended to remain less correlated to each other than stocks would be.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: In low IV environments, diversifying portfolios is easy because non-correlated underlyings are plentiful. The risk of a portfolio that only contains non-correlated stock is understated because stock correlations increase in periods of high IV. By ...
item.content:encoded: In low IV environments, diversifying portfolios is easy because non-correlated underlyings are plentiful. The risk of a portfolio that only contains non-correlated stock is understated because stock correlations increase in periods of high IV. By utilizing other asset classes and option strategies in our portfolios, we may diversify away more risk because those assets and strategies tended to remain less correlated to each other than stocks would be.

item.title: Correlations and IVR
item.description: Using low correlation underlyings is the key to reaching a large number of occurrences and reducing the risk inherent in selling option premium. tastytrader’s also tend to increase their trading activity when volatility is high in order to capture the additional profit potential. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see how correlations have varied depending on the volatility of the underlyings.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Using low correlation underlyings is the key to reaching a large number of occurrences and reducing the risk inherent in selling option premium. tastytrader’s also tend to increase their trading activity when volatility is high in order to capture...

Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see how correlations have varied depending on the volatility of the underlyings.

item.title: Effects of Rates on Sectors
item.description: Based on most recent data, there is very weak to no correlation between common sectors across all volatility profiles and short and long term interest rates. This means that when interest rates begin to rise, we don’t know what the sustained effect will be on the stock market.Keeping small positions is the only defense for volatile markets when interest rates rise.

item.title: Expected Moves in Various Volatilities
item.description:
IVR is a useful first metric for the current richness of options, while the expected range gives a theoretical one standard deviation range for future underlying prices. Both of these metrics are derived from implied volatility. 

Today, Tom and Tony look into the data to see how often prices stay within their expected ranges and how this answer changes with IVR.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: IVR is a useful first metric for the current richness of options, while the expected range gives a theoretical one standard deviation range for future underlying prices. Both of these metrics are derived from implied volatility. Today, Tom and Ton...
item.content:encoded:
IVR is a useful first metric for the current richness of options, while the expected range gives a theoretical one standard deviation range for future underlying prices. Both of these metrics are derived from implied volatility. 

Today, Tom and Tony look into the data to see how often prices stay within their expected ranges and how this answer changes with IVR.

item.title: How Does IV Move With Markets?
item.description: When looking at correlation between equity markets and IV, we see a strong negative correlation which means that they move opposite. In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, VIX (SPY IV) is about 5 times more volatile than the percentage move in SPY.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: When looking at correlation between equity markets and IV, we see a strong negative correlation which means that they move opposite. In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, V...

In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, VIX (SPY IV) is about 5 times more volatile than the percentage move in SPY.

item.title: Actual Volatility on FOMC Days
item.description: FOMC days do not make much of a difference to tastytraders because we trade over a longer timeframe (45 DTE), and the only volatility that is observed due to the meeting is in the first hour.If any argument is to be made about the day-to-day interest rate volatility on FOMC days, it is actually lower than any marker day.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: Periods of High IV
item.description:
Implied volatility (IV) is a direct measure of option prices and provides option sellers with a measure of opportunity for profits. But high IV periods also tend to be the most dynamic times for the market. How can tastytraders do their best to profit from these atypical conditions without making unfounded assumptions? 

Today, Tom and Tony dive into the data surrounding the periods of highest IV from the past 17 years and see how long they lasted and how the market moved during those times.

item.content:encoded:
Implied volatility (IV) is a direct measure of option prices and provides option sellers with a measure of opportunity for profits. But high IV periods also tend to be the most dynamic times for the market. How can tastytraders do their best to profit from these atypical conditions without making unfounded assumptions? 

Today, Tom and Tony dive into the data surrounding the periods of highest IV from the past 17 years and see how long they lasted and how the market moved during those times.

item.title: Historical Volatility Accuracy
item.description: January was a month where realized volatility was larger than IV anticipated at the beginning of the month. This happens around 1 out of every 6 months on average.From February into March, IV has remained consistently high, and the realized volatility we experienced is actually on par with what IV was anticipating.

item.title: How Long Does a Week Last
item.description: Really eventful weeks can be large shocks to the market, but contrarian tastytraders often view them as opportunities. Today, Tom and Tony explore the data to see how long lasting the effects from these extreme moves can be.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Really eventful weeks can be large shocks to the market, but contrarian tastytraders often view them as opportunities. Today, Tom and Tony explore the data to see how long lasting the effects from these extreme moves can be.
